metadata.title: Workflow Database Analysis
metadata.description:
Workflows: Database Analysis

This dataset contains all workflows and scripts to identify structure-property linkages in Kadi4Mat.
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio.

These are the uploaded workflows:

Database Preparation Workflow

(see DatabasePreparation.png)

DatabasePreparation.flow:

  • A workflow to extract data from Kadi4Mat and transform them into tfrecords

The workflow uses the scripts:

DataAcquisition.py:

  • Downloads and processes all metadata in a given collection

DataConversion.py:

  • Converts the extracted metadata into tfrecords
  • Input and output features can be selected. 

Database Training Workflow

(see DatabaseTrainingWorkflow.png)

Datenbase_Training.flow:

  • A workflow to train a neural network on the data extracted from Kadi4Mat

The workflow uses the script:

Datenbase_Training.py:

  • Implements the training of a fully connected neural network
  • Hyperparameters are passed to the script by the workflow

Database Material Map Workflow

(see Create_Materialmap.png)

Create_Materialmap.flow:

  • A workflow to create a material map from the network trained in Database_Training.flow

The workflow uses the script contained in this folder:

Create_Materialmap.py:

  • Systematically iterates over the input properties of the neural network
  • Visualises the predictions in a material map

metadata.title: RSFC: Research Software Fairness Checks
metadata.description:
• More tests added
  • Better code structure and data management
  • New table console output
metadata.notes: If you use this software, please cite it using the metadata from this file.

metadata.title: Workflow Simulation
metadata.description:
Workflows: Simulation

This dataset contains all workflows and scripts to simulate the mechanical properties of foam structures. 
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio. The simulation is performed using PACE3D.

These are the uploaded workflows: 

Simulation Workflow

(see SimulationWorkflow.png)

Simulation.flow:

  • A workflow to simulate the mechanical properties of binary foam structures
  • Downloads the foam structures from a given Collection on Kadi4Mat
  • Requires the simulation framework [PACE3D](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jocs.2018.02.011)

The workflow uses the scripts contained in this folder:

foam_mechanical_load_plastic.infile:

  • Configuration file used to parameterise PACE3D

Evaluate_Simulation.m:

  • Extracts the effective mechanical properties from the simulation results
  • Outputs compressive modulus and yield strength

metadata.title: ML-based Generation of digital twins
metadata.description:
Workflows: Generation

This dataset contains all workflows and scripts to train a DD-GAN for generating microstructures and to generate new structures using the DD-GAN. 
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio.

These are the uploaded workflows: 

Train DD-GAN Workflow

(see Training_DD-GAN.png)

DD-GAN_Training_Kadi.flow:

  • workflow to train a DD-GAN for generating three dimensional structures
  • Requires a binary image stack of the structure to mimic
  • Generation can be tuned to be conditioned by properties or images

The workflow uses the scripts:

warmup.py:

  • Creates a file that contains the information about all used subvolumes
  • Requires binary images that are used for training

Train_DD-GAN_props.py:

  • Trains a DD-GAN conditioned on structural properties
  • Outputs a structure generator 
  • Requires binary images of the structure to mimic and the info file generated by warmup.py.

Train_DD-GAN_images.py:

  • Trains a DD-GAN conditioned on images   
  • Outputs a structure generator
  • Requires binary images of the structure to mimic and the info file generated by warmup.py

Generation DD-GAN Workflow

(see Generation_DD-GAN.png)

DD-GAN_Generierung_Kadi.flow:

  • A workflow to generate three-dimensional structures using a DD-GAN
  • Requires a trained model
  • Generation can be tuned to be conditioned by properties or images
  • The workflow implements random and targeted generation

The workflow uses the python scripts contained in this folder:

warmup.py:

  • Creaes a file that contains the information about all used subvolumes
  • This file is required for the random generation

Generate_DD-GAN_props.py:

  • Generates structures conditioned on properties
  • Outputs image stacks of the generated microstructure
  • Requires binary images of the structure used for training and the info file generated by warmup.py.

Train_DD-GAN_images.py:

  • Generates structures conditioned on images   
  • Outputs image stacks of the generated microstructure
  • Requires only the trained model

metadata.title: Reconstruction and Characterisation
metadata.description:
Workflows: Reconstruction and Characterisation

This dataset contains all workflows and script to generate artificial training data and to train a segmentation U-Net. 
The workflows are implemented in the freely available workflow software KadiStudio.

These are the uploaded workflows:

Trainingdata Workflow

(see TrainingDataWorkflow.png)

ArtificialTrainingData.flow:

  • A workflow to generate synthetic training data for training a supervised segmentation network
  • Requires a GAN for creating binary images and a CycleGAN generator capable to transforming binary to grayscale.


The workflow uses the scripts:

GAN_Training.py:

  • Trains a GAN network capable of generating realistic binary images
  • Requires binary images that should be imitated

CycleGAN_Training.py:

  • Trains a CycleGAN capable of transforming binary to grayscale and vice versa
  • Outputs two generators: binary->grayscale & grayscale->binary
  •  Requires grayscale and binary images. They do not need to depict the same structure

EnhancedTrainingData.py:

  •  Outputs image stacks of grayscale images and their binary segmentation   
  • Requires a generator for binary images (output of GAN_Training.py) and a generator for transforming binary->grayscale (output of CycleGAN_Training.py)

U-Net Training Workflow

(see UNet_Training_Workflow.png)

U-Net_Model_Training.flow:

- A workflow to train a supervised U-Net to segment grayscale images
- It can either train a new network or finetune an existing one
- Requires a stack of grayscale images and their binary segmentations

The workflow uses the scripts:

U-Net_Training.py:

  • Trains a new U-Net for segmenting grayscale images
  • Requires grayscale images and their binary segmentation
  • Network can be defined by the user

Finetune_U-Net.py:

  • Finetunes an existing network for segmenting grayscale images
  • Requires a pretrained model as well as grayscale images and their binary segmentations

Segmentation Workflow

(see SegmentationWorkflow.png)

U-Net_Segmentation.flow:

  • A workflow to segment grayscale images and to reconstruct a three-dimensional volume from them
  • Requires a trained U-Net model and grayscale images

The workflow uses the scripts:

U-Net_Segmentation.py:

  • Loads a model and segments images
  • Outputs a binary images stack 

Structural Analysis Workflow

(see StructuralAnalysisWorkflow.png)

Strukturanalyse.flow:

  • A workflow to analyse the structural properties of a binary microstructure
  • Can be used on image data as well as volumetric data
  • Requires the simulation framework [PACE3D](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jocs.2018.02.011)

The workflow uses the scripts:

EraseInletOutletPores.sh:

  • Script to filter out the properties of inlet and outlet pores

metadata.title: D2.8 - Interoperable Data Spaces Framework
metadata.description: This document is the extension of D2.4, which has been the initial version of the Energy Data Space Framework, submitted in M15 of the project. It describes the Interoperable Data Space Framework and serves as a comprehensive guide to the architectural and design aspects of the software, outlining the key decisions, structures, and methodologies employed in its development. It also describes how to configure and launch the Energy Data Space Connector in a test environment.

grants.title: Interoperable opeN-source Tools to Enable hybRidisation, utiliSation, and moneTisation of stORage flExibility

metadata.title: Cloud-based prototyping for scalable software development: A study on rapid deployment and testing using amazon web services (AWS)
metadata.description: This paper examines the role of cloud-based prototyping in scalable software development, focusing on the rapid deployment and testing capabilities provided by Amazon Web Services (AWS). Traditional approaches find it difficult to meet the need for quick, scalable, and affordable prototyping as software development needs more agility. To overcome these obstacles, cloud platforms such as AWS provide adaptable, on-demand infrastructure. This study assesses how AWS products, such as Relational Database Service (RDS), Lambda, and Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2), affect prototype cycles through a number of experiments. The results show that by automating infrastructure management, AWS greatly shortens deployment times, allowing for faster application delivery. Before a full-scale deployment, developers can improve apps thanks to AWS's support for effective load testing and quick iterations. The study shows how AWS improves scalability, reduces operational overhead, and expedites testing procedures, providing useful information for businesses looking to use cloud platforms to speed up software development.

data.title: Cloud-based prototyping for scalable software development: A study on rapid deployment and testing using amazon web services (AWS)

metadata.title: From Code to Silicon: Allocating Automotive Software Components to Semiconductor Design Partitions in System-on-Chips
metadata.description:
The increasing intricacy of automotive software presents substantial obstacles when attempting to deploy applications on contemporary multi-core processors. Safety-critical systems, such as advanced driver assistance systems, require both predictability and efficiency in the allocation of resources. Traditional static allocation methods, while they are predictable, often underutilize available cores. Conversely, dynamic allocation can exploit parallelism more effectively but introduces nondeterminism and runtime overhead. This trade-off complicates the choice of suitable allocation and scheduling policies in practice.

To address this, a unified framework is presented that integrates both static and dynamic core allocation strategies with support for first-come-first-served and priority-aware scheduling. The framework is evaluated on task sets with long critical paths and balanced parallel structures, capturing realistic mixes of periodic and event-driven workloads. The findings indicate that static allocation provides determinism but entails inefficiency under parallelizable workloads. Conversely, dynamic allocation enhances throughput and reduces waiting times. The impact of priority-aware scheduling on enhancing system responsiveness is investigated, particularly in multi-core settings. The results demonstrate that while priority-aware scheduling can improve responsiveness in multi-core scenarios, it can also lead to an increase in waiting time in single-core cases. The framework systematically quantifies trade-offs in utilization, throughput, latency, and overhead, thereby providing practical guidance for reliable and efficient deployment of automotive software on multi-core platforms.

data.title: From Code to Silicon: Allocating Automotive Software Components to Semiconductor Design Partitions in System-on-Chips

metadata.title: Spatial analysis of reforestation sites in the far-north region of Cameroon
metadata.description: Following the great drought which struck the Sahel countries including the northern part of Cameroon in the mid-1970s, Cameroon, like the other states of the sub-region located on the edge of the Sahara, decided to implement implement drought control activities. This study taking place in the Far North region of Cameroon, generally fits into the field of characterization of natural environments. It aims to structure and highlight the situation of certain reforestation sites in the far north region. Therefore, to achieve the expected results, we used two specific methods of data collection, namely: the in situ method (floristic inventories using the plot method) and the indirect method (downloading of iconographic data on the SOGEFI platforms, COPERNICUS, ATLAS and GEOFABRIK), for remote sensing analysis purposes with a Landsat OLI/TIR image from November 13, 2023 and photogrammetric shots with Pix4. The inventory data and measurements taken in the field were recorded in CSV and/or XLSX formats for the purposes of statistical analyzes (PAST, Excel) or cartographic operations (Qgis versions 3.22 and 2.18). To this end, the field surveys collected in situ made it possible to carry out thematic mapping using the inverse distance interpolation (IDW) method. The processing of remote sensing data consisted of assembling satellite images using “mosaicking”, radiometric and geometric corrections, and spatial filtering using ENVI and SAGA Gis software. The analysis of these images consisted of calculating vegetation indices (the NDVI adjusted to the ground). It thus appears that the reforestation sites have a deciduous population, a natural habitat composed of shrub savannah, tree savannah, grassy savannah, steppe and meadow. Reforestation sites are sometimes less drained, sometimes very poorly drained due to the unfavorable structure and texture of the soils, in certain sites in the region. In addition, only the sites of Djiddel and Gawel 2 among the Diamaré sites have a better level of canopy, with an average regeneration rate of 36.11%. In Mayo-Kani, only the sites of Moumour, Kéra, Bipaing, Piwa, Mindif and Laf have a better level of canopy, with an average regeneration rate of 47.70%. In Mayo-Tsanaga, only the Boula-Mokong site has a better level of canopy, with an average regeneration rate of 44.66%. In Mayo-Danay, only one site has a better level of canopy, namely the Daiba-Kalfou site. Furthermore, sites in this department have an average regeneration rate of 49.25%. In Logone and Chari, most of the sites have an acceptable level of canopy since no site in this department has a very appreciable level of canopy. However, sites in this department have an average regeneration rate of 39%.
